Why the name? Back in the day, empires placated their citizens with "bread and circuses." Now we get fast food and apps. But it's all basically the same — distraction from what's REALLY happening.

card.title: Bread and Circuses (@breadandcircuses@climatejustice.social)
card.description:
Attached: 1 image

I have come to the conclusion that fighting directly against our capitalist rulers in an attempt to overthrow them will never succeed. They are too rich, too powerful, and completely unwilling to act rationally.

So our best choice now is to "be the change we want to see in the world," to demonstrate a better way of living. By doing that, we will also prepare ourselves and those we can involve in the effort to survive the coming collapse of modern industrial society and perhaps emerge from the rubble with a chance to help our species move forward.

For more on what we can do, please read this important article by Ted Trainer -- https://medium.com/postgrowth/a-friendly-critique-of-the-degrowth-movement-f0bd2297072d

Trainer's article is very long and comprehensive, so if you'd like begin with a shorter summary of it that I posted a couple of weeks ago, see this link -- https://climatejustice.social/@breadandcircuses/112410879381028836 

#Science #Environment #Climate #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #ClimateAction #Degrowth
card.image_description:
Nighttime view of a small, ecologically sustainable dwelling next to a thriving vegetable garden. Caption reads: 
      A Simpler Way 
Crisis As Opportunity

Recommend you put out blog article(s) with suggested solutions to the risks you have identified. Link them with a synopsis placed here.

Until they arrive we will flail about endlessly and simply make observations as you have, hoping someone else will take the corrective right action.

We are all selling.
Consider linking solutions to problems and your readership may multiply exponentially, particularly among those who share your values.

account.note: Ken Larson was awarded the Bronze Star during two military tours in Vietnam. His career subsequently spanned 36 years with major aerospace and defense companies and small business consulting. Ken received the SCORE National Achievement Award in 2010 and the MicroMentor Award for Outstanding Service In Mentorship in 2021. Micro Mentor and SCORE are non-profit organization offering free assistance to small business in business planning, operations, marketing and other aspects of success.

account.note:

I have lived in the seaside village of Pukerua Bay since 1988 with Kate & our four children. I occasionally blog on community and social matters, as well as myeloma and Mahayana Buddhism.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses
>Sorry to be the bearer of bad news, but it is what it is.

----

Its interesting that it's framed as "bad news", as though there's some inalienable human right to deny the laws of nature. Choose to drive Cars , fly, import beef from the Amazon etc and this is the inevitable, foreseeable result. It's like eating the last biscuit and complaining there's no more..well yes, that's what last one means, how can we say we didn't know that about the everyday horror of people participating and encouraging this behaviours?

I mention this because the language around all of this is so screwed up. It should be that driving cars, flying for holidays, taking a cruise etc is viewed as toxic behaviour. We know it is and yet we're tolerate of people engaging in ways we wouldn't tolerate less toxic behaviour, like murder. (11,000 people in Australia killed each year from car pollution, another 1500 killed in accidents, a few dozen domestic murders, the outrage is around domestic violence ?)

Everyone's seems horrified some grubby media mogul what's his dick sucked by some well paid actor who wants to get ahead (no pun intended) and yet no one calls out both their repugnant behaviours driving cars, or flying to movie shoots ? The latter enabling the complete destruction of the biosphere.

How is it that the literal toxic behaviour is so tolerated ? Popper's Tolerance of Intolerace reminds me of what happens if you let this toxic behaviour slide on by.

account.note:
I am here to learn and face the truth, not avoid it and sometimes this can alas lead to confrontation when others prefer the latter to the former.

Matrix Account: @hanrahan:matrix.org

descendants.spoiler_text: Degrowth is about more than lifestyle choices
descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses All of the major crises are interconnected, and it's too late to avoid serious harm.

It's *not* too late to reduce the severity of the climate and biodiversity crisis.

Fight for every fraction of a degree. Because every 0.01C means more suffering for humans and every other living thing. Equally, every forest saved, every species saved, every river cleaned up, every hectare rewilded, moves us closer to a sustainable future.

Even if our chances of avoiding catastrophic collapse are slim, it's still worth trying. And much of the political opposition is directly connected to the causes of the crisis: capitalism and fossil fuels.

There is plenty we can do. Capitalism as usual, lifestyle choices and "green growth" (often a lie, always inadequate) won't save us.

Renewables and green energy can slow down the crisis, if deployed fast enough. If we're lucky, and we fight hard, some form of civilisation can survive. And if we fight for socialism alongside degrowth / demand reduction measures, not only do we make faster progress towards sustainability (whether it is actually possible or not), we also help people and ecosystems to adapt to a changed world. Which beats a short-lived fascist dystopia.

The connections and alliances we make fighting to reduce climate change will also help with adapting to its impacts.

One fun fact: Extinction Rebellion still talks about Net Zero. But it means Net Zero by next year, not net zero by 2050! Of course, generally speaking Net Zero is an excuse to postpone any real action to the indefinite future based on the hope of magic technologies (sustainable aviation fuel, direct air capture etc) turning up at the last minute.

What I value personally are people and ecosystems. And as such, giving up is not an option.

Neither is Lovelock-style digging mineshafts and building nuclear reactors.

Nor are lifestyle choices, on their own. Survivalism is, in general, a game for the rich and able-bodied. That's really just another form of consumerism - not to mention eugenics. Survival as a species is not a "me" thing, it's a "we" thing.

The same is true of agrarian fantasies. We need *appropriate* technology, which includes more sustainable diets and use of land, but we still need many of the products of industrial civilisation: medicines, solar panels, buses, etc.

A slim hope beats no hope. And there remains a tiny chance that we can build a better future.

Every major social change is impossible until it is done. And history suggests our tactics (a broad campaign including non-violent direct action) are the right ones, and that we're close to achieving at least major steps towards our goal.

account.note: Former and hopefully future climate and poverty activist. Covid cautious. Autistic grey-ace/wtf-ro geek, software developer. Interested in green transition, green tech, activism, intersectionality, etc. I try to boost other marginalised voices while recognising my own privilege. Yorkshire (UK), Remainer. Climate hawk on the pro-tech end: We need *appropriate* technology. Recently re-created this account after leaving for a while during an anxious period of unemployment.
